text:
This report details exploration carried out on the One Tree tenement Project E31/566 during 
 the reporting period 07/01/2005 to 06/01/2006. 
 The One Tree Project is located approximately 130 km northeast of Kalgoorlie (Figure 1). The 
 Project  area  lies  between  Lake  Rebecca  to  the  south  and  Lake  Raeside  to  the  north  and  is 
 located  15  km  to  the  north  of  the  Porphyry  Gold  Mine.  The  tenement  is  located  on  the 
 Edjudina  1:250  000  Sheet  (H  51-06)  and  is  situated  in  the  Yerilla  District  of  the  North 
 Coolgardie  Mineral  Field.  Access  to  the  project  area  is  either  via  the  Kalgoorlie-  Yarri  – 
 Mount Celia Road or the  Kalgoorlie -  Pinjin – Edjudina road. 
 The  tenement  lies  within  the  Mulgabbie  domain  of  the  Kurnalpi  terrane.  In  this  terrane, 
 greenstone  units  form  a  west-dipping  homoclinal  sequence  that  has  been  dissected  by  late, 
 north-trending faults. The Mulgabbie domain comprises metamorphosed mafic volcanics and 
 intrusives,  predominantly  amphibolite  and  metabasalt,  minor  ultramafics  and  biotite 
 monzogranite plutons (Figure 3.). Granitoids emplaced prior to regional folding are interpreted 
 to have intruded the Yarri Domain greenstones as sheets conformable with overall greenstone 
 layering. Tenement E31/566 overlies one of these granitoid sheets. 
 Tenement E31/566 was part of a package of tenements purchased by Jackson Gold Resources 
 from Le Chem Pty Ltd in April 2004 for a cash consideration of $5000.00 and an issue of 
 25000 fully paid Jackson shares. Jackson agreed to pay Le Chem $5 per troy ounce royalty for 
 any gold produced from the tenements. 
 Exploration activities included soil auger sampling, regolith mapping and surface geochemical 
 levelling (Figure 2). 
 2

15.text: Kalgoorlie -  Pinjin – Edjudina road. Topography is subdued and the maximum relief is less

16.text: than 150m. The physiography is to a large extent related to the underlying geology. Northwest

17.text: –striking ridges are underlain by mafic rocks and banded iron-formations. Areas underlain by

18.text: greenstones and granitoids are gently undulating with plateaus of laterite and highly weathered

19.text: bedrock.  Lake  Rebecca  and  Lake  Raeside  form  two  prominent  salt-lake  drainage  systems,

20.text: stretching from northwest to southeast. The lakes are flanked by dunes separating small lakes

24.text: levelling (Figure 2). Details of the auger soil sampling is given below in Table 1.

62.text: The  One  Tree  tenements  lie  within  the  Barba  Hills  and  Yarri  Domains,  which  define  an

63.text: overall  synformal  structure,  but  are  separated  by a major regional fault, the Yilgangi Fault,

64.text: which  is  the  southern  continuation  of  the  Keith-Kilkenny  Fault.  The  fault  is  overlain  by

65.text: polymictic conglomerate and other sedimentary rocks.  Along strike to the south, the regional

66.text: stratigraphy and the major fault are parallel, and the overall structure resembles a syncline.

67.text: Both  the  Barba  Hills  and  Yarri  Domains  contain  several  basaltic  and  felsic  volcaniclastic

68.text: sequences with thin and/ or discontinuous ultramafic (komatiite) layers. Within both domains,

69.text: low angle regional shear zones bound or truncate lithologic- stratigraphic packages. The Barba

text:
The  One  Tree  tenements  lie  within  the  Barba  Hills  and  Yarri  Domains,  which  define  an 
 overall  synformal  structure,  but  are  separated  by a major regional fault, the Yilgangi Fault, 
 which  is  the  southern  continuation  of  the  Keith-Kilkenny  Fault.  The  fault  is  overlain  by 
 polymictic conglomerate and other sedimentary rocks.  Along strike to the south, the regional 
 stratigraphy and the major fault are parallel, and the overall structure resembles a syncline. 
 Both  the  Barba  Hills  and  Yarri  Domains  contain  several  basaltic  and  felsic  volcaniclastic 
 sequences with thin and/ or discontinuous ultramafic (komatiite) layers. Within both domains, 
 low angle regional shear zones bound or truncate lithologic- stratigraphic packages. The Barba

 the  Yilgarn  Craton  (Swager,  1995).  The  project  occurs  along  the  eastern  boundary  of  the 
 Norseman-  Wiluna  Belt.    The  tenement  lies  within  the  Mulgabbie  domain  of  the  Kurnalpi 
 terrane.  In  this  terrane,  greenstone  units  form  a  west-dipping  homoclinal  sequence  that  has 
 metamorphosed  mafic  volcanics  and  intrusives,  predominantly  amphibolite  and  metabasalt,  
 faults.  The  Mulgabbie  domain  comprises 
 late,  north-trending 
 minor ultramafics and biotite monzogranite plutons (Figure 3.).

20.text: The main line of workings within the Yarri Monzogranite, almost 1500 m long, encompasses

21.text: the  more  or  less  contiguous  workings  at  Wallaby  North,  Wallaby  Central,  and  Yarri

22.text: Proprietary. The workings have exposed a 330 – 340o –trending, subvertical to steeply west

23.text: dipping  shear  zone  that  is  more  or  less  conformable  within  the  regional  foliation.  The

24.text: mineralized shears are commonly located at the margins of prominent quartz veins of similar

25.text: orientation. They represent zones of relatively high strain that may have been localized by the

26.text: contrast in competency between the veins and the wall rocks. Farther south, the mafic-hosted

27.text: workings at Star of Yarri (Beatrice) and Queens Birthday, appear to lie on a different trend to

28.text: that defined by the monzogranite-hosted deposits. The structure at Yarri South is a steeply east

29.text: dipping, banded brittle-ductile shear zone (Roberts, F. I., 2000).

text:
occurred in the spoil from Granite Well. 
 3.3 Mineralisation 
 Gold mineralisation is present in several linear zones of alteration in a variety of host rocks. 
 The  Porphyry  mine  was  the  only  major  producer  (about  4.5  Mt)  in  the  area.  The  Yarri 
 Monzogranite has produced about 460 kg of gold, mainly from the Wallaby Central and Yarri 
 Proprietary  mines.  Smaller  amounts  of  gold  have  come  from  mafic-hosted  deposits  in  the 
 country  rocks.  The  main  contributor  was  the  amphibolite-hosted  Yarri  South  mine  which 
 produced 40 kg of gold (Roberts, F. I., 2000).  
 The main line of workings within the Yarri Monzogranite, almost 1500 m long, encompasses 
 the  more  or  less  contiguous  workings  at  Wallaby  North,  Wallaby  Central,  and  Yarri 
 Proprietary. The workings have exposed a 330 – 340o –trending, subvertical to steeply west 
 dipping  shear  zone  that  is  more  or  less  conformable  within  the  regional  foliation.  The 
 mineralized shears are commonly located at the margins of prominent quartz veins of similar 
 orientation. They represent zones of relatively high strain that may have been localized by the 
 contrast in competency between the veins and the wall rocks. Farther south, the mafic-hosted 
 workings at Star of Yarri (Beatrice) and Queens Birthday, appear to lie on a different trend to 
 that defined by the monzogranite-hosted deposits. The structure at Yarri South is a steeply east 
 dipping, banded brittle-ductile shear zone (Roberts, F. I., 2000).  
 The Porphyry and Million Dollar deposits occur within two 20o - 25o east-dipping shear zones 
 within  the  Porphyry  Quartz  Monzonite.  The  Porphyry  shear  zone,  which  cuts  the  eastern 
 margin  of  the  intrusion,  is  approximately  25m  wide.  Gold  is  localized  in  a  series  of  en

43.text: The surface cover in the southern half of tenement E31/566 consists of red sandy soils which

44.text: are Aeolian in part, and granite derived sandy soils forming the remainder. The north half of

45.text: the tenement is cover by colluvium and alluvium which occurs along the southern portion of

46.text: the Lake Raeside drainage system. These cover sequences are heavily indurated by hardpan

47.text: development, as observed in an old water well along the Granite Well to Forrest Well track

48.text: (Bridgen, 1997). The regolith in the area is shown in the Landsat TM Image (Figure 4).

text:
The surface cover in the southern half of tenement E31/566 consists of red sandy soils which 
 are Aeolian in part, and granite derived sandy soils forming the remainder. The north half of 
 the tenement is cover by colluvium and alluvium which occurs along the southern portion of 
 the Lake Raeside drainage system. These cover sequences are heavily indurated by hardpan 
 development, as observed in an old water well along the Granite Well to Forrest Well track 
 (Bridgen, 1997). The regolith in the area is shown in the Landsat TM Image (Figure 4).

text:
4.0 Previous Exploration 
 4.1 Exploration History 
 The Edjudina Region was first examined by prospectors at the beginning of the last centaury 
 and several gold deposits were located and worked at that time. Modern exploration began in 
 the  early  1970’s  when  the  areas  underlain  by  ultramafic  rocks  were  examined  for  nickel 
 mineralisation  but  with  no  success.  This  was  followed  by  exploration  for  volcanogenic 
 copper-  zinc  sulphide  deposits,  mainly  in  areas  underlain  by  felsic  volcanic  rocks  and, 
 although  several  base  metal  gossans  were  located,  no  economic  deposits  were  discovered. 
 Gold  exploration  in  the  region  began  in  the  late  1970’s,  and  resulted  in  the  outlining  of 
 significant gold reserves at the Porphyry deposit.  
 Forrest Well gold exploration 
 1996 – 1997 
 Companies  Sons of Gwalia Ltd 
 Sons of Gwalia’s Forrest Well historical tenement E31/228 covered the exact same area as the 
 present  tenement  E31/566.  The  tenement  was  taken  out  to  cover  possible  northerly  strike 
 extensions of structures that may control the Porphyry deposit. Three rock chip samples taken 
 of  quartz  veining  and  sericitised  felsic  rocks  in  the  vicinity  of  Granite  Well  returned  a 
 maximum value of 1 ppb Au.

text:
During the period 1990 and 1993 Pancontinental Mining Pty conducted exploration on the 
 Oak Well Gold Project which covered the western third of tenement E31/566. Exploration was 
 conducted  to  target  shear-hosted  gold  mineralisation  associated  with  splays  off  the  Keith 
 Kilkenny Tectonic Zone. The RAB drilling and reconnaissance soil sampling undertaken by 
 Pancontinental Mining Pty was not conducted in the area now covered by tenement E31/566. 
 It was concluded that the weak gold anomalism delineated from geochemical exploration did 
 not warrant further investigation. 
 4.2  Previous Exploration - Jackson Gold Resources 
 Previous  exploration  completed  by  Jackson  Gold  Resources  on  tenement  E31/566  included 
 WAMEX open file data compilation, geophysical processing and auger sampling. 
 During the 2004 reporting period soil sample and drilling data was compiled from WAMEX 
 Open file reports for the One Tree Project and adjacent areas. 
 All  available  airborne  geophysical  datasets,  which  included  gravity,  magnetic,  radiometric, 
 landsat and digital terrain model data were acquired and processed. 
 A pedogenic carbonate auger drilling programme comprising 151 holes was conducted during 
 the 2004 work year. The auger drilling was conducted on a 1000m by 100m grid. A number of 
 +20 ppb Au results were returned from five of the eight traverses. A peak value of 27 ppb Au 
 was returned from the auger drilling programme.  
 4.3  Gold Resources 
 The Yarri Monzogranite has produced about 460 kg of gold, mainly from the Wallaby Central 
 and Yarri Proprietary mines. Smaller amounts of gold have come from mafic-hosted deposits, 
 the main contributor was the amphibolite-hosted Yarri South mine which produced 40 kg of 
 gold (Roberts, F. I., 2000). 
 Significant  quantities  of  gold  have    been  extracted  from  deposits  hosted  by  the  Porphyry 
 Quartz Monzonite.  Porphyry and Million Dollar have produced greater than 4 t of Au. Present 
 inferred resources in the Porphyry Quartz Monzonite are estimated at to a further 3 t of gold or 
 more.

20.text: Regolith  mapping  was  conducted  over  Jackson  Gold’s  One  Tree  Project  area  including  the

21.text: southern third of tenement E31/566. The mapping was undertaken at a scale of 1: 25 000 by

22.text: consultant Jonno King. The mapping has been digitally captured and is presented in Figure 7.

23.text: This landform interpretation exercise was conducted over the entire project area with a view to

24.text: normalising the surface geochemistry and generating exploration targets.

28.text: Statistical  levelling  of  the  gold  from  the  surface  geochemical  database  which  includes  both

29.text: historical and recent sampling conducted by Jackson Gold for the One Tree Project area has

30.text: been  conducted  by  Jonno  King  during  the  2005  work  year.  The  geochemical  data  set

31.text: comprises numerous discrete surveys or batches, the presence of differing backgrounds and

32.text: thresholds  commonly  causes  ‘edge  effects’  that  can  obscure  real  data  trends.  Levelling

33.text: involves a statistical manipulation of the data so as to minimize batch effects which include

34.text: different sample media, sampling methods, digestion and analytical techniques and laboratory

35.text: batch results. Levelling of the data generated several new trends and anomalies and in some

36.text: case  a  better  –  constrained  existing  anomalies.  The  levelled  gold  geochemistry  data  is

text:
Regolith  mapping  was  conducted  over  Jackson  Gold’s  One  Tree  Project  area  including  the 
 southern third of tenement E31/566. The mapping was undertaken at a scale of 1: 25 000 by 
 consultant Jonno King. The mapping has been digitally captured and is presented in Figure 7. 
 This landform interpretation exercise was conducted over the entire project area with a view to 
 normalising the surface geochemistry and generating exploration targets.  
 5.3 Geochemical Data Processing    
 Statistical  levelling  of  the  gold  from  the  surface  geochemical  database  which  includes  both  
 historical and recent sampling conducted by Jackson Gold for the One Tree Project area has 
 been  conducted  by  Jonno  King  during  the  2005  work  year.  The  geochemical  data  set 
 comprises numerous discrete surveys or batches, the presence of differing backgrounds and 
 thresholds  commonly  causes  ‘edge  effects’  that  can  obscure  real  data  trends.  Levelling 
 involves a statistical manipulation of the data so as to minimize batch effects which include 
 different sample media, sampling methods, digestion and analytical techniques and laboratory 
 batch results. Levelling of the data generated several new trends and anomalies and in some 
 case  a  better  –  constrained  existing  anomalies.  The  levelled  gold  geochemistry  data  is 
 13
